'Gabon' (; ), officially the 'Gabonese Republic' () is a sovereign state on the
west coast of Central Africa. Located on the equator, Gabon is bordered by
Equatorial Guinea to the northwest, Cameroon to the north, the Republic of the
Congo on the east and south, and the Gulf of Guinea to the west. It has an area
of nearly and its population is estimated at 1.5 million people. Its capital and
largest city is Libreville.

Since its independence from France on August 17, 1960, Gabon has had three
presidents. In the early 1990s, Gabon introduced a multi-party system and a new
democratic constitution that allowed for a more transparent electoral process
and reformed many governmental institutions. Gabon was also a non-permanent
member of the United Nations Security Council for the 2010â2011 term.

Low population density, abundant petroleum, and foreign private investment have
helped make Gabon one of the most prosperous countries in Sub-Saharan Africa,
with the highest HDI and the third highest GDP per capita
(PPP) (after Equatorial Guinea and Botswana) in the region.
